author: Quadri Adejumo
title: UAE Residents Embrace Sustainable Lifestyles: A Global Momentum Towards Climate Action
text:
In a world grappling with the urgent need to combat climate change, a recent survey conducted in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) has brought to light a commendable consensus among its residents. An overwhelming 81% expressed a desire for more sustainable lifestyles to protect our planet. This sentiment aligns with the historic UAE Consensus agreement, signed by 198 nations at Cop28. The agreement marks a pivotal shift towards moving away from fossil fuels, amplifying renewable energy sources, and enhancing energy efficiency. Furthermore, it underscores the importance of building momentum towards climate finance, a critical component in our global fight against climate change.
Embracing a Sustainable Future
The UAE's commitment to sustainability is evident not only in international agreements but also in the attitudes of its residents. The support for climate-positive initiatives is palpable, with a strong call for increased transparency from suppliers regarding sustainability. This collective push towards a greener future is a testament to the growing awareness and responsibility felt by individuals and communities alike. The UAE's proactive stance on climate action serves as a beacon of hope, illustrating the impactful change that can arise from unity and shared goals.
Policy Developments and Consultations
Parallel to the UAE's strides in sustainability, Ireland and Northern Ireland are not far behind in their efforts to combat climate change. The Commission for Regulation of Utilities (CRU) in Ireland has initiated a consultation on Electricity Generation and System Services Connection Policy for onshore generators, storage, and other system services technology projects. This consultation, open until 16 February 2024, explores the policy's scope, the possibility of a bi-annual batch application process for renewable generators, and the alignment with planning processes. Additionally, it delves into whether procurement processes and the Large Customer Import Scheme (LCIS) should be encompassed within this policy. EirGrid's publication of an FAQ document on Customer Clinics further aids developers and customers, facilitating a smoother transition towards sustainable energy solutions.
In Northern Ireland, the Department for the Economy is laying down the groundwork for an offshore renewable energy action plan. This ambitious plan aims to deploy 1 GW of offshore wind from 2030, marking a significant leap towards harnessing the power of renewable energy. Meanwhile, the Maritime Area Regulatory Authority's transition to the Department of Environment Climate and Communications signifies a streamlined approach to maritime and environmental governance, promising a future where sustainable practices are at the forefront of development and policy-making.
Global Momentum towards Climate Action
The UAE Consensus, coupled with the energy policy developments and consultations in Ireland and Northern Ireland, represents a global shift towards more sustainable energy systems. The decision to accelerate efforts to phase down unabated coal power and transition away from fossil fuels underscores a collective commitment to a greener, more sustainable future. The UN and the European Commission's release of information on the UAE Consensus further highlights the international community's resolve to tackle climate change head-on, setting a precedent for nations worldwide to follow suit.
In conclusion, the push towards sustainability and climate action is gaining unprecedented momentum across the globe. From the UAE's significant strides in fostering a sustainable mindset among its residents to the policy developments and consultations in Ireland and Northern Ireland, the message is clear: the time for change is now. The historic UAE Consensus agreement and the proactive measures taken by nations to combat climate change pave the way for a future where sustainable living is not just a choice, but a way of life. As we move forward, the collective efforts of nations, communities, and individuals will be paramount in shaping a world that values and protects our planet for generations to come.

author: Liv Clarke
title: Jet2 issues 'do not travel' warning for Greek island due to 'weather disruption' - Nottinghamshire Live
text: Jet2 has issued a 'do not travel' warning to passengers heading to a Greek island, citing ' weather disruption'. The airline has halted flights to Skiathos until Saturday, May 11, and has advised customers not to head to the airport today, Friday, May 10. Customers have been instructed to go back home and only return to the airport three hours before their rescheduled departure time. Situated off Greece's east coast in the Aegean Sea, Skiathos is currently facing heavy rain, as per the UK Met Office, though conditions are expected to improve by tomorrow. Jet2 has expressed that they are keeping a close eye on the situation and extended apologies for any inconvenience this may cause to travellers. The airline stated on its website: "If you are travelling to Skiathos today, please do not travel to the airport. If you have already travelled to the airport, if possible, we would advise you to return home and come back to the airport 3 hours before your new departure time tomorrow. If it is not possible to make your way home, please speak to a member of our friendly Red team at the airport who will be happy to help." "We apologise for this change that is unfortunately beyond our control, if you are due to travel to Skiathos today, we have sent all details of the change and your options to your email address on the booking. You can also use the search function above, by entering the route you are due to fly on or the flight number, here you will find up to date information regarding your flight.", reports the Manchester Evening News . The statement further read: "Finally, it is rare for our schedules to be disrupted like this and although this change is beyond our control, we understand it will disrupt your plans at last minute and have done everything that we can to ensure we operate as soon as possible and minimise the delay."

author: @wibw
title: Emporia State's rally falls short against Rogers State, Dixon scores 28
text:
Emporia State’s rally falls short against Rogers State, Dixon scores 28
EMPORIA, Kan. (WIBW) - Despite a late rally from the Hornets, Emporia State fell short, 75-70, to Rogers State on Wednesday, Jan. 30.
Emporia State (6-14, 3-8) had a 10-point deficit at halftime, but got the game within one with 27 seconds in the second half. With a 71-70 lead, Rogers State’s (16-7, 7-4) Bernard Omooria pushed his way to the free throw line.
Omooria made both of his free throws with 14 seconds left to make the game 73-70. He would get back to the free throw line and drilled the final two points with 5 seconds left.
Rogers State would win 75-70.
Karyiek Dixon scored a game-high 28 points. Dixon shot 13-16 (81.3%) and grabbed a team-high 8 rebounds. Malik Edwards added 17 points and Devin Conley finished with 13 points and 7 rebounds.
Emporia State will host Central Oklahoma on Sunday, Feb. 2, at 3:30 p.m.
